cons: Firstly, management is non-existent, in a literal sense. As a Contract RA you don't speak with Biogen management directly, but rather to a proxy contract recruiting organization. They also pay you, so make sure to button up the details of your pay when you start, and if you believe you have something more to offer than you're worth, Biogen may be desperate enough to negotiate for that. The team you're on will truly treat you the same as a salaried hire which is respectful of them. At the same time, it is difficult because you may work just as hard as full-time employees but not be compensated as well. Also, your team may not be great so being treated the same is not necessarily good. The chances are high that your manager will be very cagey about if they can offer you a full-time position, so if you end up doing good work and are there for a while it will probably be frustrating. The other con is that because you are employed in this weird zone you'll feel "siloed" in your team, in a situation where no one outside your team wants to interact with you. All this amounts to a bad employment structure, so no, I do not recommend contract work.

You can work 60 hrs a week, far exceed expectations, do everything that is asked and more, and still your manager can do very little to reward you for that. Why bother to work 50-60 hours a week, when others work less than 40 and get the same raise? 1-2 people in the entire department get a raise sufficient to counteract inflation. pros: Fantastic people who are on the whole truly committed to what they are doing. There is real passion and desire to do the very best on most projects. Great workplace 'perks' such as free barista-style coffees and hot drinks, subsidised cantine and some great social events organised on site, such as free lunches once a month, fancy dress days and discounted cinema/theatre tickets.
cons: The company is currently going through a period of huge growth, so is moving from a small biotech to a medium/large biotech and is experiencing all the usual teething problems associated with this- lots of new people and products but without the infrastructure or processes to properly support the growth mean that things can feel a bit chaotic and disorganised. Mentalities and behaviours are slowly changing however, and many of the new people are making great changes and helping to future-proof the organisation.

review_title: Lack of Executive Leadership; Poor HR organization; Risk Averse
pros: Good benefits; good comp; great co-workers who truly believe in doing the right things and working on solutions together but don't feel empowered by leadership; flexible schedule & opportunity to work from home in most areas; summer hours (1/2 day Friday); commuter benefits;
cons: Promotion is rare; weak leadership - constantly shifting priorities, unclear governance that leads to 11th hour changes and constant revisiting of decisions; politics at upper management levels; culture has changed in recent years to make you feel more like a number and less of an individual - may be result of influx of Big Pharma executives;

pros: Great colleagues, deliveries can be made for lunch instead of cafeteria.
cons: Getting our 2019 Performance Measure in June 2019 is simply not right.  We've already worked half the year.  Too many people are giving direction and unfortunately not one is the same. So many misdirects .  Why make improvements for the sake of changing the name of the same task  so that so and so is promoted ? Or better yet- why make an "improvement" from an old process ?  Sadly, know when working here non direction , passiveness, no decision is the way of life.

pros: Excellent science; smart, passionate, loyal and dedicated employees; excellent benefits (mostly); company offers several different options for alternative transportation/transportation assistance.
cons: In desparate need of project managers and career development opportunities. Seem to be focused on bringing in outside experts who then recruit from outside, rather than retaining and developing internal talent that are interested in learning about new Tx areas, techniques, phases of drug development. Lack of awareness with regard to human resources and sustainability, i.e. we're not hiring/retaining an adequate number of individuals required to complete the work and do it to Biogen standards. Mixed messages from leadership: policies promote work-life balance and flexibility, upper leadership mandates that employees use their vacation time, but workload, overlapping projects and competing priorities won't allow for it. Employees lose unused vacation days. Bonus structure needs attention.

pros: Very, very grateful to Biogen, George Scangos, Tony Kingsley, Doug Williams, John Cox, and Paul Clancy for some truly awesome years of learning and growth. Those executives were among the best in Fortune 500.
cons:
An absolutely amazing company rotted from the inside in a matter of two years. What's left is a rotting carcass. Exodus of incredible talent, some from layoffs, others voluntarily. CEO has no idea what he is doing. 6 months behind closed doors with McKinsey talking about god knows what, in the meantime hemorrhaging the last remnants of top talent. Board made a huge mistake pushing executives out. They made some mistakes, yes, but we ditched imperfect but highly talented executives and the result was chaos and destruction. It will take years to rebuild what we had and it can't be done with this CEO.

By the way, Indeed reviews for Biogen are very clearly manipulated. Glassdoor reviews seem to be giving an honest assessment of the situation overall.

pros: bonus system, remote flexibility, inspiring mission, and solid and professional people at the working levels
cons: Poor leadership at many levels beginning with leadership team. High turnover that is concealed, trending at 15% and above. Questionable ethical practices and misrepresentation of data. Clinical organization contains a sweat shop mentality that requires a serve the boss mentality--little to no job autonomy, employees are experiencing high levels of stress and overwork. Results of employee and EHS stress surveys are buried and not acted upon. Lurches from one initiative to the next--including the latest work on lean and simple that does not have leadership committee alignment or support. Massive exit of leadership team over the last 12 months--differences over direction and strategy and accuracy of data. HR is a political cesspool where people are broken into political camps and knee jerk from one flavor of the month to the next. Don't be fooled by the latest Aducanumab announcement--the truth will emerge

review_title: Terrible place to work in IT
job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: Nice infrastructure.  Well constructed and well run.  Good validation and compliance documentation systems.
cons: Terrible management.  Almost everyone in R&D IT had only 6 months tenure when I arrived, even the VP.   It was eerie.  I've never worked at a place with so few people with any tenure greater than 2 years.  They didn't seem to have much respect for pharma industry experience, just protecting existing turf.  It was like a ghost town that was just coming back to life.  It seemed like almost everyone there was still "finding their legs".  Maybe in a few years people will start to coalesce as teams, but there was little teamwork training for new people.  Very few people knew where IT was really going.  11% employee layoffs followed 3 months later.  IT was hit hard, and so were many senior scientists.

pros:
The company has had a ton of success over the past 2 years.  It a very exciting place to work and the salary, stock, benefits are great.

There is a new focus on science and the company is throwing resources at R&D.

If you're in the right group, you will see a lot of flexibility in work arrangements (WFH, telecommuting, etc)
cons:
Management is, for the most part, awful.  There is constant infighting, finger pointing, and political jockeying.  Also, the bureaucracy is both crushing and worthless.   A good 30% of the staff are here only because they are too vested in the stock plan (golden handcuffs).

If you are applying, have a long timeframe.  HR is slow and borderline useless.  Expect rude comments, arrogance, and  lack of communication and follow-through.  In my experience, I have seen 3-6 months from first interview to offer.  You will also get low balled in salary and title.

review_title: Changing from Patient Services to a Call center environment
pros: The benefits are good. There is free soda, fruit on certain days, and donuts and muffins on Friday.
cons: Office politics, micro managing, and lateral moves within the same department. I titled my review with that title because we we have never been a call center, but there are changes that will be taking place to make us just that. New management brings about new changes, and not for the better

pros: The company is working on some amazing products that will change lives- its easy to get behind the mission. To it's credit, the company puts the patient at the center of decision making.  With success, the company has resources and uses them to provide a great roster of benefits. The place is very female-friendly with more than 50% of the workforce female.
cons: There is way too much going on. With changing leadership, changing product mix, and changing priorities, the company is swirling. The churn limits opportunities for career growth and development- no one knows what they will be working on over the next year which means they don't know how to staff their teams. People get pigeon holed in their roles and its hard to find new opportunities in the company. Managers do not make time for informational chats so its hard to know what's out there.

review_title: OK company to work for as long as you are ready to handle unexpected situations
pros: The company offers great salary and overall benefits including 200% match to 401K, Tution reimbursement and stock options with long term incentives. So you will feel financially good as long as you are employed by the company.
cons: Poor leadership, No definite direction, every new executive wants to drive the company their own way without thinking about its employees and how it was done in past. Top executives seem to beleive strongly in the philosphy that their way is always the correct way. Sad to see the employees being laid off, who have spent over 10-15 years at the company specially during this hard economic times. Financial profits are given more value than core human values. I definitely regret my decision now.

review_title: Great Company undergoing a lot of change
pros: Pros greatly outweigh cons and include pay, benefits, work life balance and the people are great.  Lots of very smart employees.  The Company is one the takes risks to bring really important products to market.
cons: There has been tremendous change at various management levels including the CEO but even one or two levels below that which impedes focus and goal achievement.

job_title: IT QA Analyst in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Good benefits and company.
Good Performance Bonus
Paid Commuter benefits
Nice facilities
cons:
No work life balance. Be ready to work very long hours. 
Too many projects and competing priorities. Difficult to plan. Projects  are not planned properly. Dates are usually set in stone without realistic planning. Employees as well as contractors need to work many hours. Only 1 day WFH although other areas or departments have more flexibility. No opportunity for growth. No development or trainings. review_title: I've felt supported from day 1 here
pros: From day 1, I've felt supported at Biogen. The benefits are great (401k match, tuition reimbursement, employee stock purchase plan, medical, free parking). There are constantly activities around campus - either educational or charitable or for just general socialization. The leadership team is strong and given the current path of our alzheimer's research it's a very exciting time to be a part of the team. Also, onboarding and IT support has been incredible here compared to other companies I've been at.
cons: General cons related to being a larger organization: lots of stakeholders, approvals needed, can be slow-moving.

review_title: Work hard, play hard culture has changed to work hard culture
pros: Good science and great location in Cambridge. Modern office spaces and facilities are good. Genuine interest and concerns for patients.
cons: So many time I have heard "this is the Biogen way". Do not propose any changes, do not criticise processes or anyone who has been with the company longer than you have. You have only been employed to confirm the Biogen process is the best. When I joined I thought this the greatest company ever.... now "tightening the belt" means that all fun has gone. There used to be    Newspapers, Christmas parties, monthly birthday cake celebrations, breakfast social meetings, brown bag training lunches, external meetings, training events and travel between sites to meet colleagues. All this has now stopped. Everyone now lives in fear for their jobs and keeping head down. In three years every person I have befriended has gone or been let go.

review_title: Great company if you work for one of the few good managers
pros: Benefits, work/life balance initiatives, internal movement to higher positions or new areas, bonus, great co-workers, ability to work at other sites - including International transfers to learn and grow at the company.
cons: There are some bad managers and there is a lack from HR or upper management to address concerns brought up seriously and without retaliation from the manager, the stock program changed where there was no longer a real long term incentive to stay with the company.

review_title: you're still an assoc.!? is what I'd hear daily
pros: Well, I never got a promotion or developed professionally,  but at least I had fun and made a lot of friends.
cons:
Expect to operate at level well above title and responsibilities. Work like there's no tomorrow. Never come close to using all vacation time. Think to self, "just work a little harder and surely you'll get promoted..." It never happens. But the benefits are good, right?

Endless number of initiatives that end up nowhere. 

Company success based on brilliance and dedication of a very. Everyone else does a good job looking busy and making presentations on nothing.

Business processes and IT infrastructure not updated in 10 years.

Performance Review...? What's that?

pros: Biogen has a very good reputation in the biotech industry and it has been very successful until it started going down the hill since 2015.
cons: Biogen has had many setbacks and did not make the right strategic decisions to stay at the top. For that reason, many employees were let go, the atmosphere started becoming toxic and many employees quit the company. One of biogen's motto is "caring deeply"; if Biogen truly cares deeply for the patients and for external stakeholders, it is untrue for its own employees.

pros: I was employed there for a little over three years. Performed more than most on my area. Free food, good benefits, and good working hours.

review_title: Review of the Black and Latinx experience ONLY
pros: Good pay, Great benefits (summer hours, eoy shutdown, unlimited sick, LTI, Bonus)
cons:
Biogen likes to boast that it is on the forefront of diversity and inclusion. That might be true when it comes to white women, but it is not the case for Blacks and Latinos. Hiring and promotions for Blacks and Latinos are practically non-existent. When one is hired, s/he is brought in at a lower level than his/her peers and usually stays at that level for eternity, even though the education and experience usually exceeds their peers. 

Promotions are practically non-existent. Boston and Cambridge are notoriously bad for promoting Blacks and Latinos. Due to their liberal image, they don't want to be accused of "Affirmative Action", so the standards are so high for Blacks and Latinos, they are unattainable in most cases. White men and women? They do just fine and will be promoted on a normal or accelerated schedule. There are many former Administrative Assistants (usually blonde) who have been put in much higher positions entry-level than most Blacks or Latinos. In fact, the unspoken secret at Biogen is that the lower job levels (1-6) are for Blacks and Latinos. And they stay there for their entire careers. 

HR, PO&T, R&D, Finance, Corporate Affairs, Legal, Compliance, have no Blacks in Leadership positions of VP or above. There are a couple Latinos. In fact the finance department doesn't seem to have any Blacks and maybe a few Latinos. Except for R&D, there are not even any Directors in those departments. They claim they can't find any "qualified" applicants. What other company doesn't have a Black person in a leadership position in HR?? The HR department JUST started hiring Blacks. How is that the "forefront" of D&I. Biogen is getting its butt kicked by the other Biotechs in this area.

If you are Black or Latino and are thinking of working here, negotiate the highest level you can, because you'll have that title for a long time, probably your entire Biogen career.

review_title: Biogen UK: Excellent benefits/perks; childish, disappointing people management
pros:
Biogen is a nice company in general, with excellent benefits and perks. 
Premises are nice, clean, the restaurant is very good, we have free coffee and fresh fruit.
The company pipeline is interesting and working with horribly disabling diseases is motivating as you can feel you help people with your work.
Flexibility is really good: working from home is allowed, flexible hours are encouraged.
The above is usually what keeps people in the company despite the Cons.
cons:
People management is the real Con in Biogen.
In some departments (I can't speak for all of them, clearly), professionals are attracted with promising talks about learning and development, but then there is no real training and no real development. There are SOPs to read, there are some soft skills courses, but there is no coaching whatsoever: you are thrown into your job with no support, and you are expected to perform brilliantly in no time. You might be assigned a reference person, but there is no coaching culture at all; they will not help and might be annoyed instead, because you represent "additional workload".
Nothing can be done about it: flagging the issue will only put you under a negative light. HR is totally useless (other than being physically absent: it's all managed via a web portal). Leadership does not really listen, despite claiming the opposite. Decision-making processes are secretive and employees are put in front of final changes about their job and career with no consultation.
Promotions do not go necessarily to people deserving them; there is in fact a nasty inclination to promote people who trump on colleagues but smile and wink to the leadership team.
Recruitment is painful: it takes ages to hire new people (and in the meantime we work like dogs to cover), they are not necessarily qualified, they are promised career development but often end up doing leg job. The best job postings are only opened in the US despite the company claiming it is a global environment.
The opinions I am sharing are not only mine; these topics are commonly discussed amongst colleagues.

pros: I loved my coworkers and the other midlevel people were brilliant and authentic. When I started at Biogen, it was the happiest time of my career. Unfortunately, my team was shielded from what was happening across the company by both location, and a former (amazing) leader who left in mid January, 2019.
cons:
Although we were shielded from the culture of "compete with your peers and win at all costs" for the first year I was employed, that changed as leaders left and were replaced with people who fit the cut throat, loose ethics environment that has been creeping in over the last several years.

Because of the reputation that Biogen has made for itself in recent years (fearing the CEO and other leaders), top talent has been hard to attract and retain. As a result, there are many process-oriented, tedious leaders in place who have never been in roles of that magnitude.  Instead of listening, or asking for advice they forge ahead not understanding the big picture, and not willing to learn. When things go wrong, it's a race to cover it up so that the CEO doesn't find out, regardless of the impact to the business. This is "fake it till you make it" on speed.

In the past 3 months, there became pressure to turn against each other for personal gain and to be dishonest to win points with senior leaders. There was also pressure to not speak up about wrong doing if you wanted to gain a promotion or favor internally. 

As an ambitious person, this was a tremendous challenge of character, and an amazing experience that taught me about who I am as a person and what I am willing or not willing to do for success. I made the right choice.

pros: The pay here is very competitive. The culture here is also amazing. I came from a nearby pharmaceutical company that was horribly negative, but Biogen cares about its employees and it’s patients. The benefits are unlike anything I’ve seen before. cons: The work politics shows in some groups and it’s a big place so hard to network and show your face.

pros: Salary, benefits, perks, happy hour, location.

review_title: Don't mess up...it will follow you!
job_title: Universal Patient Services Coordinator in Durham, NC

cons: Biogen Idec known to take the easy way out and give up on really great people who have maybe made a mistake once before that becomes hard to break from. that one instance follows you up till the point the company finds a reason to fire you.

review_title: Great company to work for, for men
job_title: Senior Associate Scientist in Cambridge, MA
pros: Very competitive salary and benefits.  Respect for work life balance.  Paid parking in Cambridge and alternative commuter options.
cons: Promotions are less based on what you know and how you perform, than who you know and how well you conform to gender "norms".  If you are a woman, be prepared to wear make-up and skirts, and understand that your salary is going to be inversely proportional to your weight.

pros: The salaries are among the highest in the industry. The benefits are almost absurd; free parking, free shuttle bus from the North, South and West, medical, dental and even vision plans etc.
cons: Since 2005 there has not been more than a 3 year period without some sort of layoff. Every time there is some sort of management change, the new boys in town feel the need to make their mark. This usually involves layoffs and it is never for financial reasons (the company has more cash than it can think of ways to be spend), it seems to just be to keep people on thei toes.

review_title: Biogen Idec is a great place to work.
pros: Biogen Idec has a strong culture, excellent values and really cares about the patients we serve.  There are many bright people across the company most of which feel a high level of loyalty to the company and commitment to our patients.  Earning potential is high, even for mid-level positions.
cons: Many departments are under resourced which results in long hours and high levels of stress.  Some of the senior management team do not want to hear bad news which causes a lack of transparency. Spent considerable time and money implementing open space floor plans that do not deliver a clear benefit.

review_title: Exposing the sordid underbelly of Biogen
pros:
It had a thriving pipeline when I was there, but it is flat now. 
My peers were smart, hardworking, and ethical, but, of course, they've all been laid off.
cons: Heartless cuts of nearly an entire department betrayed the true sentiments of executive management: we only care about the bottom line. We pretend to care about the other stuff.

pros: Checks all the benefits boxes. People you work with tend to be better than most. Recently renovated lab facilities make research less soul crushing.
cons: Upper management is a revolving door. Once new "leadership" comes in and institutes their "vision", they're gone before their changes have even been fully realized. C-level and EVPs pay more attention to stock price than the people who work here. Estimated median life expectancy for VPs and above: 2.6 years.

pros: The people are wonderful, and the company culture is great. The benefits are very competitive, the work is very, very rewarding. The work-life balance is great; they really encourage people to take and enjoy time off to reset and recharge. One of the things that I enjoy most about the company are the people that I work with and interact with on a day to day basis; could not ask for a better supervisor and team.
cons: Change from management seems reactive sometimes; communication regarding issues not directly work related could be better. There is sometimes a disconnect between the manufacturing areas and some of the development/laboratory/pilot plant areas. Some people don't take people in manufacturing very seriously, even though many individuals have the same or greater level and background in education.

pros: Great atmosphere, really a great place to work.  The benefits are unparalleled with vacation time as well as a sabbatical program with an additional paid month off once you have been there for 5 years or so.
cons: Its fast paced, but really that is a pro for a lot of people since its better than having multiple layers to navigate through

review_title: Changing culture and not really for the best
pros:
Decent work life balance but high expectations to be available at odd hours if a project demands it.  
Good benefits and fair compensation (aligns with industry)
cons: Reorganizing and consulting company analyzing processes...how can you analyze something that is a moving target?  People are constantly looking over their shoulder because they are paranoid about the next layoff which has been clearly coming based on CEO stating there is a goal to streamline processes and a consulting company analyzing processes that have been in a state of flux for a couple of years...

Lots of cross functional exposure
cons:
How will the company grow?
Limited career path/progression that is 100% subjective and depends on who you know

HR is non-existent and does not clearly articulate significant changes in the organization

review_title: Employees are GREAT .... Management is awful
pros: When working with the employees the are great, they share information they really appreciate the information you impart to them.
cons:
Management has no idea what-so-ever as to what is going on.
They complain about things they are actually the root cause of.
When you have a discussioin about a timeline which has a bearing on the conversation, they have no idea of what has happened when.
They ask you a question, you answer it and then they accuse you of being defensive.

pros: Interesting field and technologies with a chance to learn. Work with some very smart people in the research labs who were often friendly. If given the chance with an open minded manager opportunities to modernize and improve some outdated and inefficient software systems in place.
cons: Software is only a support service for them so it is not the key focus of company. Many contractors were placed in spaces without a real work space/desk making it a extra chore to get work done. Software Management did not want to listen or leverage knowledge of resources with key technological experience that could improve their applications.

pros:
- Management allows you the autonomy to contribute at your own pace with your own ideas.
- Cross functional experiences with groups inside and outside your designated department.
- Fantastic development programs such as resume building, intern lunches with VPs/former interns, etc. 
- Assigned a manager and an individual contributor for mentorship throughout the program
cons:
- Your projects are likely low priority. Thus it is often hard to gather the information needed from key stakeholders (full-time employees are very busy). 
- Little orientation on things needed in individual departement/job role e.g. jargon, acronyms, daily responsibilities.

review_title: Good place to work but it used to be much better.
pros: Good benefits, fair salary,  friendly atmosphere, very skilled people working withn this company.
cons:
Overall a good place to work but I would agree with the earlier comments about the work/ life balance. If you expect to excel you will be working in excess of 45-50 hours per week with limited time for vacation. Especially true in the engineering groups. The situation is so bad that employees were told by the director to refrain from vacation during a 4 month long shutdown.

Other cons are minimal but there has been a shift in morale over the past couple of years due to certain key management individuals and promotions.

review_title: Horrific Senior Departmental Leadership Results in Fear of Retaliation
pros: The company strives to provide excellent patient therapies and has made great corporate strides over the past few years.
cons: Some departments function on an environment of fear where senior departmental leaders are not held to the same standards as lower level employees, creating a toxic environment.  Significantly constrained resources lead to unrealistic expectations and inability to meet established goals.  Over the span of several years, it was my observation that HR does not support the employee and is swayed by political/managerial bias.

review_title: Not the company everyone used to love
job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
- Fantastic benefits
- Great, hard working peers
- Gym
cons:
- Priorities and expectations change daily making it difficult to achieve goals that were implemented six months prior.
- NO TRANSPARENCY! you go to work every day without knowing why you're doing the things you do (besides helping the patient).
- Morale is at an all time low, instead of listening to the employee silly programs are created.

pros: Great products for MS patients, some nice people too.  Great benefits, not so great salary.
cons:
Not the 'culture' that is touted by management.  Several people who work there are back-stabbers and mobbers who pull the seniority card if they are called out on it.  It's not professional.
Job requirements didn't match job description.  After 3 years, 4 management changes and reduction of my department by half, I was doing the job the senior level associate was doing when I was hired with no raise or title promotion to recognize it.

review_title: I loved the company until they decided to change my dept
pros: Good benefits, facilities, smart co-workers
cons: Top heavy, lack of decision making, grew too fast, work life balance was once promoted but cannot anymore, people are not promoted based on merit, soft skills are more important than getting work done and fear of making decisions amongst ambiguity

pros: Excellent benefits and pay, great people with a desire to help others working there.
cons: Current leadership (at least for Patient Services) is focused more on the bottom line than on the employees or the patients.

job_title: Therapy Support Coordinator in Morrisville, NC
pros: Pay is very good for the type of work you do. Benefits package is also very good. Some very talented and good people work at the company. Very interesting environment with great diversity of workers.
cons: Company is becoming transitioning from a good biotechnology company to just another big drug company. Very strict environment with minimal care about the lower scale workers. Morale has become a problem within the company. Not really a patient focused company.

pros: Amazing people, everyone is very hard working and smart. I have always been encouraged to speak to both upper level management and to those at my level if i have an issue or question. People are very open to answering questions and you are able to learn much in a very short amount of time.
cons: There is a high volume workload and you should be organized. Managers want you to be upfront and honest about how much work you can handel, so be aware of this.

review_title: Biogen Idec is a great place to work.
pros: Biogen Idec is a great company that really looks out for its employees. The employees themselves are talented, inquisitive, and understand the importance of knowledge sharing. The benefits are absolutely amazing and there is a real sense of the need for work-life balance. There is a beer hour every Friday that allows employees to meet outside of work. I would recommend a career at Biogen Idec to anyone.
cons: Because of the growing business, there are many new people, so it can be hard to get the background behind an issue that occurred a while before. It is also in downtown Cambridge, so commutes can be difficult.

pros: The benefits are great and historically the salaries have been as well. Everyone works well together in a team atmosphere and there is very little in fighting. Managers do not silo their departments.
cons: Decision making has slowed down in the non-R&D areas since the Michel has taken over as CEO and Paul as head of Operations. It is apparent the organization is slowly moving all non-R&D jobs out of Cambridge but need to get to a point of critical mass in the new locations to be able to make the full transition. These plans have created a culture of paralysis within the other areas of the organization which impacts efficient decision making.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Company has great vision and a passion to truly help the MS population. Pay was awesome and the benefits were hard to beat.
cons: Micro-mgmt was the worst. Also, leadership always asks for feedback but rarely ever took it into consideration. Patient services did not have as much growth as other divisions within the company.

review_title: Don't believe the hype. Stay away!
job_title: Information Technology Subject Matter Expert in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great medical benefits for employees. Friendly and knowledgeable staff who do the work. Profitable company who cares about patients. Great potential.
cons: Management in IT is a complete disaster from the top all the way down. Turn over is high and no one can seem to make a decision about where the organization is going. Everyone but the managers are over worked and unappreciated. Don't count on a promotion and watch out for empty promises. IT is moving towards outsourced resources or high paid contractors while the full time employees worry if they will still have a job.

pros: Biogen is an Innovative company, has a strong commitment to science; offers generous benefits; and places a premium on employee safety.
cons: High degree of instability; CEO is a tyrant and has diverted the organization from its traditional mission; Biogen used to be a rewarding place to work and fostered an environment that welcomed new ideas;  under current CEO, employees live in constant fear and survival seems to be the sole focus.

pros: Impressive product pipeline, company prospering financially, many (but not all) friendly and helpful coworkers, fun social activities, great compensation and great core values.

review_title: long time lab head, saw many changes over the years
pros: Core sciences (immunology, protein biochemistry) were, at one time, world class. The Neuro group, while weak in Discovery research, can execute on clinical development like no one else in the MS field. Company has had more positive impact on MS patients lives than all others combined.
cons: Vicious, relentless political infighting. Every department, every level, every day, played out against a vapid and hypocritical message of transparency and openness. Just vile.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Benefits are great. Perks are also great; discount tickets to events/shows. No other pros that I can think of for this company.

pros: FDA approval for multiple drugs the past few years, exciting and prosporus times.

review_title: Used to be a great company to work for.

review_title: A good place to work, but you will work hard
pros: The company has some very good products built on real scientific innovation.  The benefits are excellent and the working environment is very good.  The company has grown rapidly in recent years and a lot of very good people have joined.
cons: The excellent benefits and working environment help to distract from the fact that people are expected to work hard.   The fact that the company has grown rapidly in recent years means not every process and programme is as clear and well thought through as you might find in big pharma.

review_title: Not the company it once was...
pros: The company has good pay and and a robust benefits package. People are passionate about their jobs, smart and talented. They offer a nice sabbatical benefit for employees who've been with the company for 6 years or so.

review_title: Biogen is a much different place than a few years ago
pros: Dedicated people, benefits, social hours, good training opportunities
cons: Leadership is constantly changing things when change fatigue is a very real thing. People in senior positions only care about what makes them look good, not how it impacts their team. Work/life balance has become poor, with many drowning in work with no help in sight.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC

review_title: A good company on the brink of change

review_title: Things have definitely changed over the last couple of  years
pros: Flexible work hours, summer hours, Thursday happy hour, enough money (generally) to purchase equipment, average pay + bonuses
cons:
There is a general problem with management - they don't/won't/can't manage!  Little interest in people's career development, advancement, or dealing with issues.  There's a 'go along to get along' mentality among the management teams.  Always a reorg coming around the corner and people scrambling for cover.  Managers are unable/unwilling to articulate their vision, if it even exists.   

Morale issues in Technical Development - people lie/cheat/steal to get ahead and this is encouraged by the current administration.  People steal the work of others and claim it as their own while management refuses to address the issue even when provided with overwhelming evidence.  

Company takes surveys and then ignores the results/comments.  VP's don't want to hear anything negative and the line management refuses to communicate issues upwards as it might reflect poorly on them.   

Numerous groups don't believe in cultural/ethnic diversity and these managers use this to their advantage to bully and intimidate subordinates.   These managers won't delegate any responsibility to their team then complain about how busy they are, won't reply to emails, or VM's.  They also refuse to take accountability when deliverables are late or just plain wrong. 

Some dept heads won't hire the best candidates if they feel like 'threatened' (i.e, 'I am incompetent and they might take my job') by the skills/talents/experience of a prospective employee.  Thus you're left dealing with people who can't execute,  which leads to a variety of issues.   

Wasn't always like this but the culture has changed following numerous reorganizations, which often don't make any sense.  Place is like a ghost town in the summer - people have checked out and often 'work from home'.

review_title: Intense culture, results-oriented, but too many employees are underhanded

review_title: Fading from glory, but looking for redemption

pros: Biogen expects a lot from you but in return they give you a lot. They pay well and they try to maintain a fun and fulfilling environment.

pros:
I haven't had one day the same as another
The ability to expand my horizons is exceptional.
I love the opportunity to work for a company that is actually doing something positive and humane.
cons: The CEO is on the way out and there is a restructuring which has led to people losing their jobs and a general sense of unease that more people are going to go.

review_title: Good company, Great People, but could be better
pros: Good hard working people, train pass, RSUs, pay....  I wish the teams that I worked with and BIIB as a whole the best of luck in the future.
cons: Although BIIB is a good company, the politics and lack of personal responsibility of managment is frankly insane.  There is an incessant need to make your manager feel great about themselves which stiffles inovation.  There is little focus on what you actually accomplish.  After a managment change it was apparent to me they had promoted a great individual contributor to a management role and it was not good for anybody.  To give a view on the insanity, my new boss flew from MA to our site to "support" us for the transition where we were required to show up the next day to work to get the critical news on the move forward.  The boss expected all of us to stay out until 6AM drinking.  This ended up being a vacation and drinkng visit, and not at all about the transition.  We never discussed the transition with our new boss.  Needless to say the majority of us couldn't make it to the most critical meeting of our working lives and frankly it was embarassing that our group didn't show up to get the information. This was not the only time that we were expected to drink until we passed out when she was in town.  I am not a square, but would have like to use our time with the boss for something other than huge drink-a-thons our touring her around the country for her vacation at least once in a while.  When I finally said I can stay out but need to get back by 1AM since I have a family and need to work the next mornings, I was immediately thrown out of the inner circle.  It was the same picture for the team in MA.  They were expected to go on vacations and drinking with the boss and if they ever said no, then they were also thrown outside the inner circle.  At the end the only people getting promotions were the single team members. Having said all that, I do not begrudge the single team members who recognized that this was the only way to get promoted and there are always bad managers but the experience at BIIB overall was good.  Now that I am not in the situation at BIIB it is clear to me that there were a lot of good people BIIB, along with some poor promoting practices that allowed peple that should never manage people to direct their careers.  In the last two years since leaving BIIB, I have been promoted 3 times and work for a great company now, however still feel loyalty to BIIB, but do acknowledge there is room for them to mature the managment.

review_title: The company is not what it once was
pros: Salary, benefits and bonus.  There are some really nice people and  hard workers.
cons:
Constant reorganisations and team restructuring

Threats from upper management.   

Manipulative  managers who appease their counterparts and their managers just to make it easier for themselves and not for their team.

Opportunities for growth depends on your manager, so what's offered by the company may not be realised if your manager does not support it.

pros: Decent pay and a good variety of shifts. Met some awesome people and the company did offer some good incentives sometimes. Good benefits package.
cons: No work life balance. You get a lot of vacation but you are not able to take it when you want to and you end up losing it. Strict work environment. pros: Good employee benefits (and that's the only thing).

review_title: High quality employees in a positive environment
job_title: Associate Director in South San Francisco, CA
pros: High quality of employees, positive working environment, and excellent benefits. Management decisions are fairly transparent and data-driven. cons: The work load is greater than it should be for optimal work-life balance. Thee is some inequity in title between functional areas. Strengthen core areas rather before expanding into new areas.

pros: I love working at Biogen Idec: benefits of a large company, but the feel of a small one!  They also truly encourage moving within the company rather than losing you to another one.
cons: I guess one thing I'd have to say is that sometimes there's a lot of re-doing of work if upper-upper management gets involved and they're not overly familiar with the day to day activities.  Having said that, they're always open to hearing what the assocaited levels have to say.

review_title: A Decent Place to Work, Like Most Places
pros: Average benefits for biotech, which is above average for most other industries. Mostly good people dedicated to making patients' lives better. Reasonably current on technology with good training opportunities.
cons: There are a lot of contractors and short-term fix mentality must be challenged on a regular basis. Some administrative departments are very cliquey and can be difficult to support. review_title: Good Sr Leadership from VP level and above

cons: Managers who do a good job but treat those under them with disrespect and contempt continue to be rewarded as good managers.

review_title: Good place to work. great work life balance, a culture that values and respects employees but this is changing...
job_title: Assoc. Director, Regulatory Affairs in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Great work life balance
Great people especially those that have been in the company for a bit of time.  Not so sure about the new ones especially the new top management.  
Has been a very transparent organization (this is changing under new management)
Fabulous benefits
cons:
Has transformed into a highly bureaucratic organization. New management at the top is encouraging this and is rapidly turning the company into a highly silo'ed and bureaucratic organization where titles and political astuteness are more important and better recognized than intellectual contributions.  Company is becoming more of a political warfare zone rather than a place to work.  Something needs to be done now.
New linear organizational structure limits potential for career growth.  People in critical/responsible roles have limited to no experience in the job.  Others who do the work thus suffer. 
No leadership from middle management.  They are just stuck up on titles.

Company relying heavily on prior management decisions that are only now beginning to finally bring results.  No evidence of leadership from new management who seem not very focussed on securing the future but for short term decisions to boost stock price. 
The value addition to the organization in firing hundreds of employees, cutting core therapeutic areas and new culture of "NEXT" remain questionable.  Narrow pipeline or products are disease focussed rather than therapeutic area focussed.

review_title: Zug office just not the same
pros: Salary, benefits, salary, benefits, easy to get promoted
cons: When I started in supply chain here in the initial stages, I was greeted by an engaged team and a fully competent leadership that knew how to get things done. We worked very hard and felt appreciated. The manager I had has long left Zug and the new leadership from other Big Pharma doesn't understand what it was that attracted us to this group. There is good intention, but going from best in class to blah does not excite me anymore.  I was hired as a supervisor and had many promotions so far.  I could have never been promoted this much if I worked for another company.  I do miss my old boss who I could actually learn from.  Sometimes I think everyone will be able to tell that I don't know what I am doing but nobody seems to care.  I no longer have a mentor.  It has become a paycheck and nothing else.  Who likes to see all the hard work they put in go down the drain?  I am paid very well, but really I stopped learning years ago and really I work with employees who have checked out or who come in inexperienced. The ideas of junior scientists are not valued and contractors are treated well but strung along for years. In my opinion a contractor should never be renewed for a second year... if they're worth renewing, they're worth hiring FT. We're not talking about 16 year old kids, we're talking about adults who would like to have health insurance and 401k plans provided by their employer.

Junior and mid-level scientists are taught to fall in line, don't rock the boat, and never stand against convention or you will be flogged through a concerted effort of "powers that be". I see people come straight out of college with the same excitement and fresh ideas that the CEO and top executives are always talking about, but middle management does not have the same appetite for risk and 7 levels later, it's like working for contrary accountants, not innovative scientists and engineers. 

All of these things are mostly isolated to the "little brother" RTP site in my experience. There is not any company sponsored social hour in RTP, while Cambridge has weekly social "hour" from 4-7 where beer, wine and appetizers/snacks are served. RTP feels like a forgotten little brother by comparison. When we launched a new drug, all of Cambridge went to Fenway Park to celebrate and cavort for hours, leaving work early and partying into the evening. In RTP, we celebrated in the Biogen courtyard from 12-2 and then wen't back to work. They were nice enough to provide us with a Fenway Park backdrop, in case we wanted to have a picture taken for the "Outta The Park!" theme. There was banana pudding and iced tea.

There is also a lot of talk about internal mobility and the value of a diversely trained work force, but in reality most of the people who are hired into mid and upper level positions have been doing the same job for years, only at a different company. There is a strong push for anyone wanting to advance their career to leave the company. People are routinely hired in at hire levels than peers with the same experience and education profile, and the longer you work there, the worse the disparity gets.
